choices.text: Posterior Aortic Sinus
Coronary Sinus
Left aortic Sinus
Anterior Aortic Sinus

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents to the clinic with complaints of recurrent episodes of fatigue, dizziness, and syncope, especially during physical activity. On examination, her blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg, and a systolic murmur is heard along the left sternal border. An echocardiogram reveals severe aortic stenosis. Right coronary artery origin part was affected. Where does the right coronary artery originate from?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anterior Aortic Sinus

 

Option D:

 

  • Right coronary artery arises from anterior/right aortic sinus.

 

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Posterior Aortic Sinus is located just above the aortic valve. The right coronary artery does not arise from this sinus. Instead, it's typically the non-coronary sinus or occasionally the left coronary artery that is associated with the posterior aortic sinus.

 

Option B. Coronary Sinus is on the posterior aspect of the heart. The right coronary artery is not connected to the coronary sinus as it is an artery, not a vein.

 

Option C. Left Aortic Sinus, also known as the left posterior aortic sinus. This sinus is typically the origin of the left coronary artery. The left coronary artery branches into the left anterior descending artery and the circumflex artery, supplying blood to the left side of the heart.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Anterior Aortic Sinus, also known as the right anterior aortic sinus, is the correct origin of the right coronary artery.
  • The right coronary artery arises from this sinus and travels down the right side of the heart, supplying blood to the right atrium, right ventricle, part of the left ventricle, the sinoatrial node and the atrioventricular node.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 265

choices.text: Posterior Part of Inter-ventricular Septum
Anterior Wall of Left Ventricle
Lateral Part of Heart
Inferior Surface of Right Ventricle

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset chest pain radiating to his left arm and associated diaphoresis. An electrocardiogram (ECG) shows ST-segment elevation in leads V1 to V6. Which area of the heart is most likely affected by the occlusion of the Left Anterior Descending (LAD) artery in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anterior Wall of Left Ventricle

 

Option B:

 

  • LAD supplies the sternocostal surface of the left ventricle and anterosuperior 2/3rd   interventricular septum.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Posterior interventricular artery arising from right coronary artery supplies posteroinferior 1/3rd interventricular septum.

 

Option C. Left coronary artery supplies the left atrium, left ventricle, part of right ventricle (sternocostal surface close to anterior interventricular groove).

 

Option D. Right coronary artery supplies the right atrium, right ventricle and diaphragmatic surface of the left ventricle close to the posterior interventricular groove.

 

Educational objective:

 

Anterior Wall of Left Ventricle:

 

  • The LAD artery primarily supplies the anterior wall of the left ventricle, the anterior portion of the septum, and the apex of the heart.
  • Occlusion of the LAD artery can lead to a myocardial infarction in these areas, often referred to as an "anterior wall myocardial infarction."
  •  This can be a serious condition due to the large area of the heart muscle that the LAD supplies.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 265

choices.text: Crista Terminalis
Thebesian Valve
Mitral Valve
Eustachian Valve

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents with recurrent episodes of palpitations and dizziness. An echocardiogram reveals an enlarged right atrium and evidence of a right-to-left shunt. During the cardiac catheterization procedure, the cardiologist observes a valve-like structure within the right atrium. Which of the following structures guards the opening of the coronary sinus and may be contributing to the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thebesian Valve

 

Option B:

 

  • In this clinical scenario, the patient is experiencing palpitations and dizziness, suggesting the possibility of an abnormal shunt within the heart.
  • The Thebesian valve, also known as the valve of coronary sinus, is a structure within the right atrium that guards the opening of the coronary sinus.
  • If this valve is abnormally developed or functioning, it can potentially lead to right-to-left shunting of blood, causing symptoms like those described. Therefore, option B is the correct answer.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Crista terminalis is a smooth muscle ridge which extends from the upper part of the atrial septum to the right horn of the IVC valve.

 

Option C. Mitral valve guards the left atrioventricular orifice.

 

Option D. The Eustachian valve guards the opening of IVC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coronary sinus opening is situated in the lower part of interatrial septum and opening is guarded by thebesian valve.

 

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 263

choices.text: Right Atrium
Great Cardiac Vein
Coronary Sinus
Marginal Vein

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with crushing chest pain radiating to the left arm and neck. An electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads, and a diagnosis of acute anterior myocardial infarction (MI) is made. The patient is taken to the catheterization lab for coronary angiography. In patients with acute anterior MI, which structure does the anterior cardiac vein primarily drain into?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right Atrium

 

Option A:

 

Anterior cardiac veins do not drain into any tributary of coronary sinus rather they drain directly into right atrium

 

This vein plays a significant role in the drainage of blood from the anterior part of the heart.

 

Following drain into right atrium

  1. Superior vena cava
  2. Inferior vena cava
  3. Coronary sinus
  4. Anterior cardiac veins

Note - Vena cardia minimi drain into all 4 chambers of the heart and not just into the right atrium.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Great cardiac vein opens into the coronary sinus.

 

Option C. Coronary sinus receives about 60% venous blood and is 2 to 3 cm long.

 

Option D. Venae cordis minimi open into different chambers of the heart through foramina minimarum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior cardiac veins, sometimes called the right marginal vein, open in the atrium proper through foramina venarum.    

 

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 267

choices.text: Anterior Inter-Ventricular Sulcus
Posterior Inter-Ventricular Sulcus
Anterior Atrio-Ventricular (AV) Groove
Posterior Atrio-Ventricular (AV) Groove

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient presents to the cardiology clinic with complaints of chest pain and shortness of breath, particularly during physical activity. An exercise stress test reveals significant ST-segment depression on ECG, indicating myocardial ischemia. The cardiologist decides to perform coronary angiography. In patients with symptoms of myocardial ischemia, which of the following locations is most likely to be drained by the middle cardiac vein?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior Inter-Ventricular Sulcus

 

Option B:

 

  • In this clinical scenario, the patient is experiencing symptoms suggestive of myocardial ischemia during physical activity.
  • The middle cardiac vein, also known as the posterior interventricular vein, typically courses in the posterior interventricular sulcus (sulcus of the heart), which is associated with the posterior part of the heart.
  • This vein plays a role in draining blood from the posterior aspect of the heart and is relevant in cases of myocardial ischemia and coronary artery disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anterior interventricular sulcus lodges Left anterior descending artery and great cardiac vein.

 

Option C. Right coronary lodges in the right part of the anterior atrioventricular groove.

 

Option D. Coronary sinus lodges in the left part of the posterior atrioventricular groove.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior interventricular sulcus lodges posterior interventricular artery and middle cardiac vein.

 

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 270

choices.text: IVC
Oesophagus
Aorta
Greater Splanchnic Nerve

questions.text: A 3-week-old male infant is brought to the pediatric clinic by his parents due to persistent respiratory distress and feeding difficulties since birth. The baby appears to have labored breathing, and the parents report that he frequently vomits after feeds. On physical examination, the infant is tachypneic with retractions and decreased breath sounds on the left side. A chest X-ray shows abdominal contents in the left thoracic cavity, confirming the diagnosis of a diaphragmatic hernia.  Which of the following structure passes through the marked opening in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oesophagus

 

Option B:

 

  • This is a case of diaphragmatic hernia through marked opening.
  • Pointed opening is for the oesophagus that lies opposite the T10 vertebra.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. IVC opening is located opposite the T8 vertebra.

 

Option C. Aortic opening lies opposite T10.

 

Option D. Greater and lesser splanchnic nerves pierce each crus.

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

Oesophageal branches of left gastric vessels, anterior and posterior vagal trunks pass through esophageal opening.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 211

choices.text: Venae Cordis Minimi
Oblique Vein of Left Atrium
Small Cardiac Vein
Great Cardiac Vein

questions.text: Venous drainage of the heart removes deoxygenated blood, preventing myocardial congestion and maintaining cardiac function, while also serving as a diagnostic tool in cardiology. Which of the following veins does not open into the pointed structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Venae Cordis Minimi

 

Option A:

 

  • The pointed structure in the given image is coronary sinus.
  • All veins of heart drains into right atria except 2: 
    • Venae cordis minimi (smallest vein of the heart)
    • Anterior cardiac vein
       
  • In below diagram of right atria direct opening of Venae cordis minimi are shown-

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Oblique Vein of Left Atrium runs on the posterior surface of the left atrium and is a remnant of the left superior vena cava. The oblique vein of the left atrium drains into the coronary sinus, contributing to its blood flow.

 

Option C. Small Cardiac Vein runs along the right margin of the heart and drains the right atrium and ventricle and typically drains into the coronary sinus, contributing to the venous drainage of the heart.

 

Option D. Great Cardiac Vein begins at the heart's apex and runs alongside the anterior interventricular artery. It drains into the coronary sinus, forming one of its major tributaries.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Venae Cordis Minimi, also known as Thebesian veins, these are small veins that drain directly into all four chambers of the heart, mostly the right atrium and right ventricle. They do not typically drain into the coronary sinus.
  • Instead, they open directly into the heart chambers, particularly the atria.
  • Venae cordis minimi opens into different chambers of heart through foramina minimarum.

 

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 261

choices.text: The girl was diagnosed to have coarctation of aorta
Notching of ribs is due to dilatation and tortuosity of posterior intercostal arteries
The ligamentum arteriosum extends from pulmonary trunk to the descending aorta distal to the origin of left subclavian artery
There is reversal of blood flow in posterior intercostal arteries

questions.text: A 28-year-old girl realized that she felt very exhausted and tired after a short walk. She also experienced leg cramps and shortness of breath. On examination, radiofemoral delay was noted and BP in the upper limb was 110/80 mmHg and in the lower limb was 90/60 mmHg. Chest x-ray showed notching of ribs. Echocardiography showed narrowing of the archof the aorta beyond attachment of ligamentum arteriosum. All the statements pertaining to the above condition are correct except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The ligamentum arteriosum extends from pulmonary trunk to the descending aorta distal to the origin of left subclavian artery.

 

Option C:

 

  • Ligamentum arteriosus is small fibrous band which extends from the proximal part of the left pulmonary artery to the aorta distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery.
  • Ligamentum arteriosus is remnant of ductus arteriosus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. In postductal coarctation of aorta, descending aorta receives blood from enlarged and tortuous posterior intercostal arteries of 3rd to 9th spaces.

 

Option B. These arteries in turn receive blood from the anastomoses with anterior intercostal arteries from the internal thoracic artery and its musculophrenic branch.

 

Option D. Posterior intercostal arteries of upper two spaces arise from superior intercostal arteries and rest of the spaces directly from descending aorta.

 

Educational objective:

 

Ligamentum arteriosum extends from the proximal part of the left pulmonary artery to the aorta distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st edition, pg no. 1024

choices.text: The SA Node is supplied by Left Coronary Artery
Coronary predominance is based on origin of Anterior Interventricular Branch
The Interventricular Septum is supplied only by Right Coronary Artery
The trunk of Left Coronary Artery is very short

questions.text: A cashier in a bank who prefers to eat deep fried foods and ice cream daily before bed, on his way home suddenly felt an uneasiness in the left side of his chest. He managed to drive to a nearby hospital. The physician advised him to take a coronary angiogram. Which of the following is true about arterial supply to the heart?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The trunk of left coronary artery is very short

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The SA node and AV node are supplied by branches of the right coronary artery.

 

Option B. Coronary predominance is based on the origin of the posterior interventricular branch.

 

Option C. Anterior 2/3rd of the interventricular septum is supplied by the left coronary artery and the posterior 1/3rd by right coronary artery.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The trunk of the left coronary artery is very short it soon bifurcates into the anterior interventricular branch and left circumflex artery.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st edition, pg no. 995

choices.text: The left anterior descending artery lies in the anterior interventricular sulcus
It is accompanied by great cardiac vein
It supplies anterior 2/3 of interventricular septum
It anastomoses with the posterior interventricular branch at the apex of the heart

questions.text: A 57-year-old male lorry driver presented to his local emergency department with a 20-minute episode of diaphoresis and chest pain. The chest pain was central, radiating to the left arm and crushing in nature. The pain settled promptly following 300 mg aspirin orally and 800 mcg glyceryl trinitrate (GTN) spray sublingually administered by paramedics in the community. On examination, he appeared comfortable and was able to complete sentences fully. There were no heart murmurs present on cardiac auscultation. Blood pressure was 180/105 mmHg, heart rate was 83 bpm and regular, oxygen saturation was 97%. He was taken to the catheterization lab where the left anterior descending coronary artery (LAD) was shown to be completely occluded. Which of the following statements is incorrect about LAD?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It anastomoses with the posterior interventricular branch at the apex of the heart

 

Option D:

 

  • Left anterior descending branch anastomosis with the posterior interventricular branch of the right coronary artery at the junction of anterior one third and posterior two third of posterior interventricular groove.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The LAD (Left Anterior Descending artery) is also called the AIVA (Anterior Interventricular Artery) in some texts. The LAD runs down the anterior interventricular sulcus, supplying the sternocostal surface of the heart and the anterior part of the interventricular septum.

 

Option B. The great cardiac vein (GCV) does indeed accompany the LAD/AIVA in the anterior interventricular groove.

 

Option C. The LAD provides blood to the anterior 2/3 of the interventricular septum, which includes the bundle branches of the heart's electrical conduction system.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Left anterior descending branch anastomose with the posterior interventricular branch of the right coronary artery at the junction of anterior one third and posterior two third of posterior interventricular groove.
  • While the LAD does extend to the apex of the heart, the main anastomosis at the apex is between the terminal branches of the LAD and the posterior descending artery.
  • The PDA is often a branch of the right coronary artery (in right-dominant circulation) or a branch of the circumflex artery (in left-dominant circulation).

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st edition, pg no. 1016

choices.text: Lumbricals
Palmar Interossei
Dorsal Interossei
Adductor Pollicis

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with a history of hypertension and diabetes is admitted to the hospital with complaints of weakness in the hand and difficulty holding objects. The patient's medical history includes a recent cerebrovascular accident (CVA). A "card test" is performed as part of the neurological examination. Which of the following muscle groups is primarily assessed with this test to check for motor function in the hand?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Palmar Interossei

 

Option B:

 

  • Palmar interossei causes adduction of digits. (Mnemonic: PAD- Palmer interossei are adductor)
  • They are responsible for adducting the fingers towards the middle finger.  The card test is used to assess the function of the palmar interossei.
  • During this test, a patient is asked to hold a card between two fingers. Difficulty in holding the card can indicate weakness in the palmar interossei, which would compromise the adduction strength of the fingers.

 

 

  • Card test is done to test adduction of fingers by palmar interossei.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.

 

  • Lumbricals are involved in flexing the metacarpophalangeal joints and extending the interphalangeal joints.
  • The lumbricals are not directly tested by the card test. This test is more focused on the adduction and abduction of fingers, which are not the primary actions of the lumbricals.

 

 

Option C.

 

  • Dorsal Interossei are responsible for abducting the fingers away from the midline. 
  • While the dorsal interossei are important for finger movements, they are primarily involved in abduction, not adduction. Therefore, they are not the primary focus of the card test.

 

 

 

Option D.

 

  • Adductor Pollicis is responsible for adducting the thumb.
  • This muscle is not specifically evaluated by the card test. The adductor pollicis is typically tested by other maneuvers, such as asking the patient to grip something between the thumb and another finger.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Palmar Interossei are responsible for adducting the fingers towards the middle finger. The card test is used to assess the function of the palmar interossei.
  • During this test, a patient is asked to hold a card between two fingers. Difficulty in holding the card can indicate weakness in the palmar interossei, which would compromise the adduction strength of the fingers.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 170

choices.text: Median Nerve
Ulnar Nerve
Radial Nerve
Musculocutaneous Nerve

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents to the clinic with a complaint of difficulty pointing their index finger. On examination, it is noted that the patient has weakness in flexing the index finger at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint, while the other fingers remain unaffected. Which nerve is most likely to be affected in this patient's injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Median Nerve

 

Option A:

 

  • In this case patient has weakness in flexing the only the index finger at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint is indicating the positive pointing index sign, which is seen in case of median nerve damage.

 

 

  • Median nerve injury at mid forearm causes paralysis of Flexor digitorum profundus (lateral ½) innervated by anterior interosseous nerve, branch of median nerve. Due to lesion at mid forearm mainly index finger muscle fibres are affected. Hence index finger can’t be flexed.
  • Medial ½ of FDP supplied by ulnar nerve. Hence 3 & 4 fingers can be easily flexed.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Ulnar nerve injury will result in claw hands.

 

 

Option C. Radial nerve injury results in wrist drop.

 

 

Option D. Injury to musculocutaneous nerve results in inability to flex elbow joint (brachialis, biceps brachii paralysis) and loss of cutaneous sensation over lateral aspect of forearm (Lateral cutaneous nerve of forearm).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inability to flex the distal phalanx of index finger is called pointing index which occurs due to paralysis of Flexor digitorum profundus innervated by anterior interosseous nerve, branch of median nerve.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 165

choices.text: Flexor Digitorum Superficialis
Median Nerve
Radial Artery
Flexor Digitorum Profundus

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents to the clinic with symptoms of numbness and tingling in the median nerve distribution of the hand. During the examination, the physician discusses the anatomy of the wrist and flexor retinaculum. Which of the following structures does NOT pass under the flexor retinaculum in the wrist?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radial Artery

 

Option C:

 

  • This is the case of carpal tunnel syndrome which occurs due to compression of median nerve below the flexor retinacula.

 

 

 

 

  • 5 structures passes above flexor retinacula shown in image:

 

 

 

  • From image it’s clear that radial artery has no relation with flexor retinacula. Superficial branch of radial artery passes above flexor retinacula. Hence answer is Option C.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Flexor Digitorum Superficialis tendons pass under the flexor retinaculum. They are part of the tendons that travel through the carpal tunnel and are involved in flexing the fingers.

 

Option B. Median Nerve also travels under the flexor retinaculum. It is a significant structure within the carpal tunnel and is responsible for the sensory and motor innervation of parts of the hand.

 

Option D. The tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus also pass under the flexor retinaculum. Like the flexor digitorum superficialis, these tendons are involved in the flexion of the fingers and travel through the carpal tunnel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Radial Artery, one of the major arteries of the forearm, does not pass under the flexor retinaculum.
  • It travels on the lateral side of the forearm and wrist and does not enter the carpal tunnel.
  • Radial artery enters the palmar surface of the hand by passing between two heads of the first dorsal interossei.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 131

choices.text: Card Test
Egawa Test
Pen Test
Froment's Sign

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents to the neurology clinic with complaints of weakness and clumsiness in their hand, particularly involving the ulnar-sided fingers. The physician is evaluating for possible ulnar nerve injury and discusses various diagnostic tests during the examination. Which of the following tests is NOT typically used to detect ulnar nerve injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pen Test

 

Option C:

 

  • Pen Test is another method used to evaluate ulnar nerve function. 
  • Patient is asked to touch the pen using the thumb, which in turn test the thenar muscles (mainly abductor pollicis brevis) supplied by the median nerve.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Egawa Test is less commonly referenced and not a standard test for ulnar nerve functions. It's not typically associated with the assessment of ulnar nerve injury.

 

Option D. Froment's Sign is a clinical test specifically used to identify ulnar nerve palsy. The test involves asking the patient to grip a piece of paper between the thumb and index finger. If the patient flexes the thumb’s distal phalanx (due to weakness in the adductor pollicis, which is innervated by the ulnar nerve), it indicates a positive Froment's sign.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

Card Test is used to assess the function of the palmar interossei muscles, which are innervated by the ulnar nerve. The test involves holding a card between two fingers (other than the thumb) and can reveal weakness in these muscles, indicating potential ulnar nerve injury.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 165

choices.text: Fracture of Scaphoid has a Low incidence of Non Union
Scaphoid Bone Articulates with Five Bones totally
Scaphoid Bone can be easily Immobilized
Fracture Line on the Scaphoid Bone may deprive the Distal Fragment of its Arterial Supply

questions.text: A 22-year-old male was referred to the emergency room after a fall from height on stretched left wrist. Pain, tenderness were noticed in the region of the anatomical snuff box of her left hand. X-ray showed fracture of scaphoid bone. Identify the correct statement:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scaphoid Bone Articulates with Five Bones totally

 

Option B:

 

  • Scaphoid bone articulates with Radius (proximally), Trapezium & Trapezoid (distally), Lunate and Head of Capitate (medially).

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.

 

  • Scaphoid fractures actually have a relatively high incidence of non-union.
  • This is due to the peculiar blood supply of the scaphoid, where the blood enters the bone distally and travels proximally.

 

 

  • In case of a fracture, especially in the proximal part, this can lead to avascular necrosis and non-union.

 

 

Option C.

 

  • Immobilization of the scaphoid bone can be challenging due to its location and the range of movements in the wrist.
  • Proper healing often requires a specific type of cast or splint known as GLASS HOLDING CAST that immobilizes not just the wrist but also the thumb, as movement of the thumb can disturb the scaphoid.

 

 

Option D.

 

  • In scaphoid fractures, it's typically the proximal fragment that is at risk of losing its blood supply, not the distal fragment.
  • This is because the blood supply to the scaphoid enters distally and travels proximally.
  • If there is a fracture, especially in the proximal part, it can compromise the blood flow to the proximal fragment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scaphoid Bone Articulates with Five Bones Totally: The scaphoid bone, one of the carpal bones in the wrist, articulates with five other bones: the radius proximally; the trapezium distally on the thumb side; and the lunate, capitate, and trapezoid on its ulnar side.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st edition, pg no. 868

choices.text: It is located on the dorsal aspect of hand and becomes visible when the thumb is fully abducted.
Floor is formed by styloid process of radius, base of first metacarpal bone
Medially by tendon of extensor pollicis brevis
Laterally by extensor carpi radialis longus

questions.text: All of the following statements are incorrect about the pointed Area A in the given image except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Floor is formed by styloid process of radius, base of first metacarpal bone

 

Option B:

 

  • The question says choose which of the following is incorrect except, i.e., the students needs to choose which of the following is correct 
  • The pointed area A in the given image is Anatomical Snuff Box (ASB)
  • All the statements given are incorrect except option B.
  • Floor of ASB is formed by-
    • Styloid Process of Radius
    • Scaphoid
    • Trapezium
    • Base of 1st Metacarpal

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.

 

  • This statement is incorrect. The anatomical snuffbox is located on the dorsal (back) aspect of the hand and becomes more prominent when the thumb is hyperextended.

 

 

Option C.

 

  • This statement is incorrect. The postero medial border or boundary of the anatomical snuffbox is indeed formed by the tendon of the extensor pollicis longus muscle. This muscle plays a role in extending the thumb at the metacarpophalangeal joint.

 

 

Option D.

 

  • This statement is also incorrect. The antero lateral border or boundary of the anatomical snuffbox is indeed formed by the tendon of the abductor pollicis longus and Extensor pollicis brevis. This muscle extends the wrist and abducts the hand.

 

Educational Objective:

  • Anatomical Snuff Box (ASB) - From proximal to distal, floor is formed by the styloid process of radius, scaphoid, trapezium and base of first metacarpal bone. Radial artery crosses the floor.
  • Postero - Medial border is formed by - EPL (Extensor pollicis longus)
  • Antero - lateral border is formed by - EPB (extensor pollices brevis) & APL (Abductor pollicis longus)
     

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, upper limb and thorax, Vishram Singh, 3rd edition, pg. 101

choices.text: The median nerve of the right hand is injured.
There is weakness of thenar muscles on the right side
The adductor pollicis of the right side is weak
The flexor muscles of the thumb of the right hand is weak

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents to the orthopedic clinic with complaints of progressive weakness in his right hand. The patient reports difficulty in fine movements of hand. Doctor performed a test over patient as shown in image. Which of the following statements is true about the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The adductor pollicis of the right side is weak

 

Option C:

 

  • Patient is having difficulty in fine movement of the hand which clearly indicates that this question is about the ulnar nerve. Because the ulnar nerve is considered as the nerve which is responsible for fine movements since it supplies 15 out of 20 muscles of the hand.
  • The above image shows Froment’s sign/ Book test/ Adductor Pollicis Test.
  • At thenar eminence the adductor pollicis muscle is supplied by ulnar nerve and the test shown in the image is checking the adductor muscle of thumb (thenar eminence) hence in turn it is checking the ulnar nerve.
  • Due to an injury of the ulnar nerve the patient is unable to adduct his thumb.
  • All the thenar muscles are supplied by the median nerve except adductor pollicis which is supplied by the ulnar nerve.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The median nerve is not injured as the inability to adduct the thumb is due to injury to the ulnar nerve.

 

Option B. The thenar muscles are innervated by the median nerve. Hence no weakness of thenar muscles on the right side will be found because damaged nerve in this case is ulnar nerve.

 

Option D. The flexor pollicis brevis muscles is supplied by the median nerve and flexor pollicis longus is supplied by the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve in the forearm. So, they are not weak on the right side.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The adductor pollicis is innervated by a deep branch of the ulnar nerve and causes adduction of the thumb. The patient is unable to adduct his thumb due to paralysis of adductor pollicis which is supplied by the ulnar nerve. He tries to hold the book by flexing his thumb.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, upper limb and thorax, Vishram Singh, 3rd edition, pg. 131

choices.text: The scaphoid is the largest carpal bone
Trapezium is the largest carpal bone
Pisiform bone is not seen in this x-ray
Lunate is the smallest carpal bone

questions.text: An eight-year-old male child managed to take his board game from the loft after standing on top of two chairs one over the other. But while trying to get down, he fell down from the topmost and experienced severe pain over his right hand, back & leg. The image given is his x-ray. Which of the following statements is true pertaining to the given case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pisiform bone is not seen in this x-ray

 

Option C:

 

  • Pisiform is sesamoid bone, smallest carpal bone & last carpal bone to ossify.
  • It ossify between 9 to 12 years of age.
  • Since the age of child is 8 years hence it is not ossified & not visible in X ray.

 

Ossification of carpal bones are shown in sequence in image below:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The scaphoid is not the largest carpal bone; capitate is the largest carpal bone.

 

Option B. Trapezium is also not the the largest carpal bone.

 

Option D. Pisiform is the smallest carpal bone, not the Lunate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pisiform bone is the: 
    • Smallest Bone
    • Last Bone to ossify (12th year)
    • Sesamoid Bone (within the tendon of flexor carpi ulnaris)
    • Capitate is the largest of carpal bones and starts ossification first.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 29

choices.text: Subscapularis
Supraspinatus
Teres Major
Teres Minor

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents to the orthopedic clinic with a history of shoulder pain and limited range of motion. The physician suspects rotator cuff pathology and discusses the relevant muscles during the examination. Which of the following muscles is NOT considered part of the rotator cuff group and is not typically associated with rotator cuff injuries?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Teres Major

 

Option C:

 

  • Teres major is inserted into medial lip of inter tubercular sulcus which is away from position of rotator cuff. That’s why teres major is not the rotator cuff muscle.

 

 

  • There are 4 rotator cuff muscles (Mnemonic SItS)
    • S- Supra spinatous
    • I- Infra spinatous
    • t- teres minor (Not the Teres major)
    • S- Subscapularis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Subscapularis is innervated by upper and lower subscapular nerves.

 

Option B. Supraspinatus and infraspinatus are innervated by suprascapular nerve.

 

Option D. Teres minor is innervated by the axillary nerve. Teres major is innervated by lower subscapular nerve.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Subscapularis, supraspinatus, infraspinatus and teres minor form the rotator cuff muscles.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 73

choices.text: Flexion Shoulder
Extension Shoulder
Internal Rotation Shoulder
Adduction Shoulder

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient is seen in the Orthopedic clinic for complaints of shoulder pain and limited range of motion following a recent injury. During the examination, the physician assesses the patient's shoulder muscles and their functions. Which of the following actions is NOT typically caused by the deltoid muscle?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adduction Shoulder

 

Option D:

 

  • Deltoid Muscle (Middle Fibres) causes Abduction of the shoulder from 0 degree to 90 degree according to new concept.

 

 

  • Deltoid Action: 
    • Anterior Fibres- Flexion & medial rotation at shoulder.
    • Posterior Fibres- Extesion & lateral rotation at shoulder.
    • Deltoid Does not participate in adduction of the shoulder joint. The adduction of the shoulder joint is brought by latissimus dorsi and pectoralis major

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anterior fibres of deltoid arising from the clavicle causes flexion and internal rotation of the shoulder joint.

 

Option B. Posterior fibres of deltoid arising from spine of scapula causes extension of shoulder joint.

 

Option C. Internal rotation is the rotation toward the midline. The muscles subscapularis, pectoralis major, latissimus dorsi, teres major and the anterior fibres of deltoid. 

Deltoid is innervated by the Axillary nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Anterior Fibers:
    • Primary Action: Flexion of the shoulder joint.
    • Additional Actions: Medial (internal) rotation and horizontal adduction of the arm at the shoulder joint.
       
  • Middle Fibers:
    • Primary Action: Abduction of the arm at the shoulder joint. The middle fibers are particularly crucial for this movement, especially from 15 to 90 degrees of abduction. The initial 0 to 15 degrees of abduction is primarily facilitated by the supraspinatus muscle.
    • Additional Actions: These fibers contribute to stabilization of the shoulder joint during various arm movements.
       
  • Posterior Fibers:
    • Primary Action: Extension of the shoulder joint.
    • Additional Actions: Lateral (External) rotation and horizontal abduction of the arm at the shoulder joint.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 57

choices.text: Deltoid
Supraspinatus
Serratus Anterior
Pectoralis Major

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents to the clinic with a recent shoulder injury following a fall. The patient complains of pain and difficulty lifting their arm away from the body. During the examination, the physician assesses the muscles responsible for shoulder abduction. Which of the following muscles is NOT primarily responsible for causing abduction at the shoulder joint?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pectoralis Major

 

Option D:

 

  • In this case abductors of shoulder are affected.
  • Pectoralis major is adductor of shoulder that’s why it is answer.

 

 

  • Abduction of the shoulder:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Deltoid causes abduction of the shoulder from 0 to 90 degrees.

 

Option B. Supraspinatus initiates abduction upto 90 degrees according to latest update from Gray’s anatomy.

 

Option C. Serratus anterior, trapezius causes overhead abduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pectoralis major causes flexion, adduction and medial rotation of shoulder joint.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 71

choices.text: Middle 1/3rd is most common site for clavicle fracture.
Sternocleidomastoid muscle elevates the medial fragment of the fractured bone
Lateral fragment is pulled medially by contraction of trapezius
Coracoclavicular ligament prevents dislocation of acromioclavicular joint

questions.text: A 40-year-old man stumbled down a flight of stairs and experienced severe pain over his right shoulder. X-ray showed fracture in the middle third of the right clavicle. He entered the emergency room supporting his sagging right upper limb with his opposite hand. The following statements concerning this case are all true except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lateral fragment is pulled medially by contraction of trapezius

 

Option C:

 

  • When clavicle fractures, the trapezius is unable to hold the lateral fragment up owing to the weight of the upper limb hence, the shoulder drops.

 

 

  • Instead the lateral fragment can be pulled medially by the adductor muscles of the arm.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 

 

  • According to Allman’s classification 80% of clavicle fracture at middle 1/3rd.

 

 

 

Option B. After a fracture of the clavicle, the sternocleidomastoid muscle can elevate the medial fragment due to its attachment to the clavicle and its relative strength.

 

Option D. The coracoclavicular ligament, which attaches the clavicle to the coracoid process of the scapula, plays a crucial role in stabilizing the acromioclavicular joint. In cases of clavicle fractures, especially if the fracture is lateral enough, this ligament can prevent complete dislocation of the acromioclavicular joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lateral Fragment is Pulled Medially by Contraction of Trapezius:
  • In the event of a clavicle fracture, the lateral fragment is typically pulled downwards by the weight of the arm and the pull of the shoulder muscles, particularly the deltoid muscle. The trapezius muscle, on the other hand, helps support the shoulder and clavicle but does not typically pull the lateral fragment medially.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st edition, pg no. 776

choices.text: Acromioclavicular Joint Subluxation
Posterior Dislocation of Humerus
Rotator Cuff Tear
Anterior Dislocation of Humerus

questions.text: A 26-year-old right-handed female tourist was excited to plunge into the swimming pool. After 15 minutes of breast stroke swimming, she suddenly felt her right shoulder going out of place and unable to continue swimming. She described the feeling and the sound as a “pop” during the pull phase of the stroke. In physical examination the right shoulder was in slight abduction and external rotation. There was flattening of the right shoulder and overlying skin insensitive to pinprick. Which of the injuries is most likely possible?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anterior Dislocation of Humerus

 

Option D:

 

  • Shoulder joint is the most commonly dislocated major joint in the body.
  • Anterior dislocation: most common type. It injures the Axillary nerve related to the surgical neck of the humerus.
  • The attitude of the shoulder as described in the question that the shoulder was in abduction and external rotation indicates anterior dislocation.
  • This occurs because the humeral head is displaced anteriorly and inferiorly relative to the glenoid cavity. This position is maintained by muscle spasm as any attempt at adduction or internal rotation increases pain. 
  • The numbness in the skin (regimental badge area) occurs due to injury to the axillary nerve, which is commonly damaged during anterior shoulder dislocations as it wraps around the surgical neck of the humerus.
     

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acromioclavicular Joint Subluxation involves partial dislocation where the clavicle separates from the acromion but not completely. It typically results from direct blows to the shoulder or falls on an outstretched arm.  It would generally cause pain and swelling over the acromioclavicular joint rather than a 'Pop' sound or the sensation of the shoulder going out of place.

 

Option B. Posterior Dislocation of Humerus is less common and often result from seizures or electric shocks, which cause violent muscle contractions. The shoulder would typically be held in internal rotation, not external rotation, in the case of a posterior dislocation.

 

Option C. Rotator Cuff Tear involves a tear in one or more of the rotator cuff muscles and is a common injury in overhead activities. Although it can be painful and limit shoulder movement, a rotator cuff tear does not typically lead to dislocation or the 'pop' sensation as described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior Dislocation of Humerus is the most common type of shoulder dislocation and can occur from trauma or unusual arm movements like those in swimming. It often presents with the arm in slight abduction and external rotation, a visible deformity or flattening of the shoulder contour, and can be associated with a 'pop' sound or sensation. Neurovascular compromise, such as numbness can occur due to the dislocation's impact on nearby nerves.

 

Axillary Nerve:

 

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st edition, pg no. 813

choices.text: It inserts into Coracoid Process
The Second part of Axillary Artery lies behind structure marked as A
Its Upper border is accompanied by superior thoracic artery
Its contraction causes Upward rotation of Glenoid cavity of Scapula

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about the structure labelled A in the given image except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Its contraction causes upward rotation of glenoid cavity of scapula

 

Option D:

 

The structure labelled A in the above image is Pectoralis Minor Muscle.

 

Its contraction causes protraction, depression of the scapula and downward rotation of the glenoid cavity of the scapula and not upwards as mentioned in option D.

 

The question is asking which of the following is incorrect hence D is the answer.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.  Correct statement. It originates from 3rd to 5th ribs and inserts into the medial border and upper surface of the coracoid process.

 

Option B.  Correct statement. The axillary artery is divided into 3 parts by pectoralis minor muscle. Among  which the second which second part lies behind the pectoralis minor.

 

Option C.  Correct statement. Its upper border gives attachment to clavipectoral fascia. Lower border is accompanied by lateral thoracic artery and upper border by superior thoracic artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Its contraction causes protraction, depression of the scapula and downward rotation of the glenoid cavity of the scapula.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, upper limb and thorax, Vishram Singh, 3rd edition, pg. 33

choices.text: It is a Plane Synovial Joint
It is a type of Suture Joint
Coracoclavicular Ligament serves as a Syndesmosis
During dislocation the Acromial Process is driven below the Lateral end of clavicle

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about the coloured joint in the given image except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is a type of Suture Joint

 

Option B:

 

  • The pointed structure is acromioclavicular joint, between lateral end of clavicle & medial margin of acromion process of scapula.
  • It is example of plane synovial joint not the sutures.
  • Sutures are classically found in skull bones.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.

 

  • Acromioclavicular joint is a plane synovial joint which allows only gliding movement.

 

Option C.

 

  • Coracoclavicular ligament connects the clavicle to the coracoid process of scapula. Hence it acts as syndesmosis ligament.
  • It is a strong stabilizer of the acromioclavicular joint and helps in weight transmission of the upper limb.

 

Option D.

 

  • The clavicular facet on acromion process faces laterally and downward to meet the acromial facet which is inclined in opposite direction.
  • Hence, during dislocation the acromial process is driven below the lateral end of the clavicle.

 

Educational objective:

 

The articular surfaces are covered with fibrocartilage, which is a unique feature of acromioclavicular joint.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, upper limb and thorax, Vishram Singh, 3rd edition, pg. 153

choices.text: Palmaris Brevis
Dorsal Interossei
Extensor Pollicis Longus
Flexor Pollicis Brevis

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents to the clinic with weakness in the thumb and difficulty gripping objects. On examination, the patient exhibits a loss of opposition of the thumb, as well as atrophy of the thenar eminence. Which of the following muscles is primarily supplied by the median nerve and is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Flexor Pollicis Brevis

 

Option D:

 

  • In this case thumb/thenar muscles are involved which are supplied by median nerve (except Grave yard of ulnar nerve i.e.- adductor pollicis which is supplied by ulnar nerve.)
  • Among given options only Flexor pollicis brevis is thenar muscle hence it is the answer.
  • 4 Thenar Muscles shown in image:

 

 

  • 4 Hypothenar Muscles shown in image:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Palmaris brevis is innervated by the superficial branch of the ulnar nerve.

 

Option B. All dorsal interossei are innervated by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve.

 

Option C. Extensor pollicis longus is innervated by the posterior interosseous nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flexor pollicis brevis, Opponens pollicis, Abductor pollicis brevis, first and second lumbricals in the hand are innervated by the median nerve.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 166

choices.text: Brachialis
Brachioradialis
Anconeus
Flexor Carpi Radialis

questions.text: All of the following muscle causes flexion of the forearm except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anconeus

 

Option C:

 

  • Anconeus is muscle of extensor/posterior compartment of forearm. It doesn’t participate in flexion of forearm.
  • Anconeus causes screwing movements.
  • Its actions are:
    • Elbow Extension: The primary function of the anconeus is to assist in extending the elbow joint. It works in conjunction with the triceps brachii, the major extensor of the elbow.
    • Stabilization of the Elbow Joint: The anconeus also helps stabilize the elbow joint, particularly during forearm movements.
    • Forearm Supination and Pronation: Some anatomical studies suggest that the anconeus may play a minor role in supination and pronation of the forearm, although these actions are mainly performed by other muscles like the supinator and pronator teres.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Brachialis inserts into the ulnar tuberosity and causes flexion of the forearm.

 

Option B. Brachioradialis is the muscle of the extensor compartment but causes flexion of the forearm.

 

Option D. Flexor carpi radialis is innervated by the median nerve and causes flexion of the forearm.

 

  • 5 Muscles of flexor compartment of forearm (Superficial group) shown in below image:

 

 

  • 3 Muscles of flexor compartment of forearm (deep group) shown in below image:

 

 

  • 7 Muscles of extensor compartment of forearm (Superficial group) shown in below image:

 

 

  • 5 Muscles of extensor compartment of forearm (deep group) shown in below image:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anconeus is a small muscle located at the Posterior aspect of the elbow.

 

Elbow Extension: The primary function of the anconeus is to assist in extending the elbow joint. It works in conjunction with the triceps brachii, the major extensor of the elbow.

 

Stabilization of the Elbow Joint: The anconeus also helps stabilize the elbow joint, particularly during forearm movements.

 

Forearm Supination and Pronation: Some anatomical studies suggest that the anconeus may play a minor role in supination and pronation of the forearm, although these actions are mainly performed by other muscles like the supinator and pronator teres.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Upper limb and thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 101

choices.text: Supination and pronation takes place at the elbow joint
Triceps brachii is a powerful supinator
In children less than 6 years, annular ligament is larger in diameter and head of radius can be pulled out
The pronators of forearm are supplied by median nerve

questions.text: A four year old boy while playing in the park, tried to get down from the merry-go-round all by himself but eventually fell down. His father came running towards him and picked him up with both hands. The boy started to cry and said his right elbow hurt a lot. The doctor who examined him found that the boy held his right elbow semi-flexed and forearm pronated. Identify the correct statement.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The pronators of forearm are supplied by median nerve

 

Option D:

 

  • Both C and D are correct but D is the better option in this case since it is evidently mentioned that right elbow is semi flexed and forearm is pronated.
  • Pronator teres and pronator quadratus are muscles of anterior compartment of forearm.
  • Hence these are supplied by nerve of anterior compartment of forearm ie. median nerve. (Hilton’s law)
  •  

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Supination and pronation takes place at the superior and inferior radioulnar joint not at elbow joint.

 

Option B. Biceps brachii and supinator causes supination. Triceps brachii causes the extension of the forearm at the elbow joint. and has no role in supination. Also, its long head contributes to the extension and adduction of the arm at the shoulder joint.

 

Option C. In children less than 6 years, the head of radius is smaller in size than the annular ligament and it can be pulled out. This is incorrect because - The father did not pulled the arm of the child as per the statement in the question. This could have been the first choice of answer if the attitude of the limb was not mentioned in the question or there was some evidence of pull of elbow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pronator teres and pronator quadratus are muscles of anterior compartment of forearm.
  • Hence these are supplied by nerve of anterior compartment of forearm ie. median nerve. (Hilton’s law)

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st edition, pg no. 846

choices.text: It causes Dorsiflexion of Foot at the Ankle Joint
It is supplied by Superficial Peroneal Nerve
It is the Strongest Tendon of the Human Body
Its inserts into the Upper Third of Calcaneus

questions.text: A 47-year-old obese man felt a snap in his right lower leg while playing squash and couldn’t continue the game further. He reached the emergency department with complaints of acute severe pain in his right lower leg and heel. The physician confirmed a diagnosis of an acute right Achilles tendon rupture, and the patient was immediately posted for open reparative surgery. Which of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is the Strongest Tendon of the Human Body

 

Option C:

 

  • Achilles tendon is formed by the union of tendons of Gastrocnemius, soleus and plantaris muscles.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. It causes dorsiflexion of foot at the ankle joint: The Achilles tendon, formed by the confluence of the gastrocnemius and soleus muscles, is actually responsible for plantarflexion of the foot at the ankle joint, not dorsiflexion. Plantarflexion is the movement that points the toes downward, which is essential for actions like pushing off while walking or standing on tiptoes.

 

Option B. It is supplied by superficial peroneal nerve: The muscles that form the Achilles tendon, namely the gastrocnemius and soleus muscles, are innervated by the tibial nerve, a branch of the sciatic nerve. The superficial peroneal nerve, on the other hand, primarily innervates muscles in the lateral compartment of the leg, which are involved in eversion of the foot.

 

Option D. It inserts into the upper third of calcaneus: The Achilles tendon actually inserts into the posterior aspect of the calcaneus, not specifically into the upper third. It attaches near the mid-region of the calcaneus, providing the leverage necessary for plantarflexion of the foot.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The Achilles tendon is known to be the strongest and largest tendon in the human body.
  • It can withstand great tensile forces, which is essential for the transmission of forces from the calf muscles to the foot, enabling activities like running, jumping, and climbing.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition, Pg no. 1409

choices.text: The Flexor Retinaculum Forms the Medial Wall of Tarsal Tunnel
The Medial Malleolus lies in Front of the Tunnel
The Tibial Nerve lies medial to Flexor Hallucis Longus Tendon
The Heel Pain is due to Injury to Medial Plantar Nerve

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presented with complaints of progressive intermittent pain in the right foot for the past two months. The pain and burning sensation were located on the foot extending from medial malleolus along the plantar surface of the sole to toes. The patient also complained of heel pain. Prolonged standing and walking aggravated the symptoms. Which one of the following statements is not correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The Heel Pain is due to Injury to Medial Plantar Nerve

 

Option D: This statement is incorrect. Within the tarsal tunnel, the tibial nerve gives rise to a medial calcaneal branch, then divides into medial & lateral plantar nerve. Heel pain is due to injury to the calcaneal branch.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The flexor retinaculum forms the medial wall of the tarsal tunnel: The flexor retinaculum, also known as the laciniate ligament, is a strong fibrous band that covers the tarsal tunnel on the medial side of the ankle. It forms the roof or the superior border of the tarsal tunnel and holds the tendons, nerves, and vessels in place as they pass from the leg into the foot. Flexor retinaculum extends from the anterior border of tibia malleolus to the back of calcaneus.

 

 

 

Option B. The medial malleolus lies in front of the tunnel: The tarsal tunnel is located posterior to the medial malleolus. The medial malleolus is a bony prominence on the inner aspect of the ankle, forming part of the tibia, and the tarsal tunnel lies just behind it. Structures passing through flexor retinaculum include tibialis posterior tendon, flexor digitorum longus, posterior tibial artery, posterior tibial vein, tibial nerve & flexor hallucis longus.

 

Option C. The tibial nerve lies medial to flexor hallucis longus tendon: In the tarsal tunnel, the tibial nerve is positioned medial relative to the tendon of the flexor hallucis longus. The tibial nerve is one of the structures that run within the tarsal tunnel.

 

Direction of structures from medial to lateral in tarsal tunnel

  1. Tendon of tibialis posterior
  2. Tendon of flexor digitorum longus
  3. Posterior tibial artery and its branches
  4. Posterior tibial nerve and its branches
  5. Tendon of flexor hallucis longus
     

Educational Objective:

 

  • While the medial plantar nerve, a branch of the tibial nerve, could contribute to heel pain, it's more common for heel pain to be associated with plantar fasciitis or other causes.
  • The medial plantar nerve typically provides sensation to the sole of the foot and pain specifically due to its injury would more likely be localized to the areas it innervates (the medial three and a half toes and the associated sole area), not just the heel.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy Abdomen and Lower Limb, 3rd Edition, Vishram Singh, Volume II, Pg. 405

choices.text: Artery of Head of Femur is a Major Source of Blood Supply to the Hip Joint
Avascular Necrosis is more common in Extracapsular Fracture
Retinacular Arteries Travel Deep to the Synovial Membrane
Nutrient Artery to Femur originates from Obturator Artery

questions.text: An 80-year-old gentleman was received in the Accident and Emergency Department at 3:00 am. He was an independent gentleman with no significant comorbidities. That night after dinner, he had emptied his water bottle. Around 2 am, he woke up to empty his bladder. On the way to reach the switchboard, his foot skidded over a slippery surface and he sustained a fall. Clinical examination revealed external rotation of both legs and pain on passive movement of both hips. X-ray pelvis showed completely displaced intracapsular hip fracture on both sides. Which of the following is true about blood supply to the hip joint?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Retinacular Arteries Travel Deep to the Synovial Membrane

 

Option C: This statement is true

 

  • Retinacular arteries travel in the retinacula of the capsule of the hip joint deep to the synovial membrane.
  • They play a key role in providing nutrition to the head & neck of the femur.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Artery of head of femur is a major source of blood supply to the hip joint: The artery of the head of the femur (a branch of the obturator artery) does contribute to the blood supply of the head of the femur, but it is not the major source, especially in adults. In adults, the primary blood supply to the femoral head comes from the medial and lateral circumflex femoral arteries, specifically through their retinacular branches.

 

Option B. Avascular necrosis is more common in extracapsular fracture: Avascular necrosis (AVN) is more commonly associated with intracapsular fractures, not extracapsular fractures. Intracapsular fractures can disrupt the blood supply to the femoral head, leading to AVN, while extracapsular fractures typically do not affect this blood supply as severely.

 

Option D. Nutrient artery to femur originates from obturator artery: The main nutrient artery of the femur typically originates from the profunda femoris artery, not the obturator artery. The profunda femoris artery is a major branch of the femoral artery and provides significant blood supply to the femoral shaft.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The retinacular arteries, branches of the medial and lateral circumflex femoral arteries, travel along the neck of the femur deep to the synovial membrane and are responsible for the main blood supply to the femoral head.
  • These arteries are susceptible to injury in intracapsular hip fractures, leading to a risk of AVN.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition, Pg no. 1379

choices.text: The Sciatic Nerve lies Infero-Posterior to Hip Joint
The Femoral Nerve lies Anterior to Hip Joint
Acetabulum Covers approximately 70% of the Femoral Head during all Manoeuvres
Sensory Deficit over Anteromedial Aspect of Thigh and Medial Side of Leg should Raise Suspicion of Injury to Femoral Nerve

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy was struck by a car while walking. He was promptly taken to the nearest hospital by emergency responders, approximately 30 minutes after the accident. On examination, the right femoral head was visibly protruding from the inner side of the thigh. However, pulsation of the ipsilateral dorsalis pedis artery was noted, and there were no signs of neurological damage. The initial X-rays indicated an anterior dislocation of the right hip. Based on this scenario, which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acetabulum Covers approximately 70% of the Femoral Head during all Manoeuvres

 

Option C: This is an incorrect statement

 

  • In a healthy hip joint, the acetabulum covers approximately 40% of the femoral head during all the maneuvers.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The sciatic nerve lies infero-posterior to the hip joint: The sciatic nerve arises from the lumbosacral plexus and descends infero-posteriorly in the thigh. It passes beneath the piriformis muscle and travels down behind the hip joint. Given its location, the sciatic nerve can potentially be injured in posterior dislocations of the hip, though this wasn't the type of dislocation described in the presented case.

 

 

Option B. The femoral nerve lies anterior to the hip joint: The femoral nerve arises from the lumbar plexus, specifically from the dorsal divisions of the second, third, and fourth lumbar nerves. It descends through the fibers of the psoas major muscle and enters the thigh beneath the inguinal ligament, supplying the anterior thigh muscles. Given its anterior position, the femoral nerve can potentially be at risk in anterior traumatic events involving the hip, such as anterior hip dislocations.

 

Option D. Sensory deficit over the anteromedial aspect of the thigh and medial side of the leg should raise suspicion of injury to the femoral nerve:  The femoral nerve provides sensory innervation to the anteromedial aspect of the thigh. If there's an injury to the femoral nerve, it can result in sensory deficits in its dermatomal distribution, which includes the anteromedial thigh. Femoral nerve gives of a branch named saphenous nerve which provided innervation to the medial aspect of the leg 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The acetabulum is the socket of the hip joint, formed by parts of three pelvic bones (ilium, ischium, and pubis). It holds the head of the femur to constitute the hip joint.
  • In a healthy hip joint, the acetabulum covers approximately 40% of the femoral head during all the maneuvers.
  • This coverage provides stability to the joint while allowing a wide range of movements.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Abdomen and Lower Limb, 3rd Edition, Vishram Singh, Volume II, Pg. 378

choices.text: The Head of Femur is not developed
It Ossifies from a Single Secondary Centre that appears around 2nd year after birth
The Epiphyseal Plate Between Head & Neck of Femur is Horizontal upto 12 years
The Head of Femur is a Pressure Epiphyses

questions.text: A male child developed a right-sided limp some days after his second birthday. His parents took him to see their general practitioner (GP) as they had noticed that the child had been limping on his right side for a day. The GP then referred him to the emergency department (ED) for an urgent paediatric orthopaedic opinion. On examination, the child was afebrile with stable vital signs and appeared to have a full pain free range of movement at both hips and both knees. However, he was noted to have an antalgic gait with a limp on the right side. Plain film radiographs & MRI further confirmed the diagnosis of Perthes disease. Which of the following statements is true pertaining to the pointed structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The Head of Femur is a Pressure Epiphyses

 

Option D: This statement is true.

 

  • The pointed structure is the head of the femur which collapsed in Perthes disease due to avascular necrosis.
  • The head & lower end of the femur is a pressure epiphysis.
  • There are 4 types of epiphyses shown in image:

 

 

  • Perthes disease, also known as Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease, is a childhood hip disorder initiated by a temporary disruption of blood flow to the femoral head.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The head of femur is not developed: In Perthes disease, the head of the femur is developed but undergoes avascular necrosis due to disrupted blood supply. This condition does not indicate an absence or lack of development of the femoral head, but rather a disruption in its normal maturation and integrity.

 

Option B. It ossifies from a single secondary centre that appears around 2nd year after birth: The ossification of the femoral head begins from a single secondary center, which ossifies from a single secondary centre that appears around 6 months to one year after birth.This ossification center is crucial for the proper development of the femoral head, and its disruption can lead to conditions such as Perthes disease.

 

Option C. The epiphyseal plate between head & neck of femur is horizontal up to 12 years: The epiphyseal plate between the head & neck of the femur is horizontal initially and becomes oblique by the 8th to 12 years. The orientation of the epiphyseal plate between the head and neck of the femur changes as a child grows. The statement that it remains horizontal up to 12 years oversimplifies this developmental process.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The head of the femur is classified as a pressure epiphysis. Pressure epiphyses are found at the ends of long bones where they are subjected to pressure and contribute to lengthwise growth of the bone.
  • The femoral head, as a pressure epiphysis, is important in bearing the weight of the body and enabling growth in length of the femur.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Abdomen and Lower Limb, 3rd Edition, Vishram Singh, Volume II, pg. 375

choices.text: Dorsum of Foot
Lateral Compartment of Leg
Anterior Compartment of Leg
Posterior Compartment of Leg

questions.text: An 18-year-old female while driving her Two-Wheeler accidentally collided with a Car from the Opposite side on her way to college. She failed to balance her vehicle and eventually fell down while the vehicle dropped over her left lower leg. X-ray revealed fracture of Lower Fibula and Cast was applied. Few days after this, she developed Pain and Numbness over most of the Dorsum of her Left Foot and had difficulty in turning her sole outwards. Which could be the most probable sight of Nerve Compression in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lateral Compartment of Leg

 

Option B: This is the most probable site of nerve compression in this patient

 

  • In the context of an 18-year-old female who sustained a lower fibula fracture and later developed pain and numbness over most of the dorsum of her left foot along with difficulty in turning her sole outwards.
  • Superficial peroneal nerve pierces deep fascia behind anterior intermuscular septum at the junction between upper 2/3rd and lower 1/3rd.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Compression at the dorsum of the foot could affect the superficial peroneal nerve, which supplies sensation to most of the dorsum of the foot. However, the superficial peroneal nerve travels through the lateral compartment of the leg, and its compression is more likely to occur higher up in the leg rather than at the level of the dorsum of the foot.

 

Option C. While the anterior compartment contains muscles and nerves involved in dorsiflexion of the foot, the specific symptoms of numbness over the dorsum of the foot and difficulty in eversion point more towards the lateral compartment and peroneal nerve involvement.

 

Option D. The posterior compartment of the leg mainly contains muscles and nerves associated with plantarflexion of the foot. Compression in this area is less likely to cause the symptoms described, such as numbness over the dorsum of the foot and difficulty in eversion.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The peroneal nerve, particularly the common peroneal nerve, wraps around the neck of the fibula and then divides into superficial and deep branches.
  • The deep peroneal nerve innervates the muscles that help in dorsiflexion and eversion of the foot.
  • Compression or damage to these nerves in the lateral compartment, especially following a fibular fracture, could lead to the symptoms described.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition, Pg no. 1415

choices.text: Femoral Hernia
Indirect Inguinal Hernia
Direct Inguinal Hernia
Spigelian Hernia

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a painful swelling in his right groin area. On physical examination, a bulge is noted at the mid inguinal point, which is located midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic symphysis. This finding is most suggestive of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Indirect Inguinal Hernia

 

Option B: Indirect Inguinal Hernia is the most common type of hernia in both men and women. It protrudes at the mid inguinal point, which is a landmark used to distinguish between direct and indirect inguinal hernias.

 

The indirect inguinal hernia lies lateral to inferior epigastric vessels hence the bulging is seen at the level of midinguinal point.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Femoral Hernia: Typically appears below the inguinal ligament, more common in women. The location described in the question does not correspond to the typical site of a femoral hernia.

 

Option C. Direct Inguinal Hernia: Occurs medially to the inferior epigastric vessels and typically presents in older men. It protrudes through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal, which is not at the mid inguinal point.

 

Option D. Spigelian Hernia: Occurs along the spigelian fascia, which is found lateral to the rectus abdominis muscles. This is not consistent with the location described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Indirect Inguinal Hernia is the most common type of hernia in both men and women. It protrudes at the mid inguinal point, which is a landmark used to distinguish between direct and indirect inguinal hernias.
  • This type of hernia follows the path of the inguinal canal and often protrudes into the scrotum in men.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Abdomen and Lower Limb, 3rd Edition, Vishram Singh, Volume II, pg. 55

choices.text: Gluteus Maximus
Biceps Femoris
Adductor Magnus
Iliopsoas

questions.text: A 22-year-old athlete presents with pain in the posterior aspect of his hip after a sprinting injury. On examination, the pain is localized to the ischial tuberosity. Which of the following muscles is most likely involved, given its attachment to the ischial tuberosity?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biceps Femoris

 

Option B: The long head of the biceps femoris originates from the ischial tuberosity. This muscle is commonly involved in sprinting injuries, and pain at its origin point, the ischial tuberosity, is a key indicator of its involvement. 

Short Head of Biceps Femoris doesn't originate from Ischial Tuberosity. So not included in the Hamstring Group of Muscles 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Gluteus Maximus: Although it is a posterior hip muscle, the gluteus maximus primarily attaches to the gluteal tuberosity of the femur and the iliotibial tract, not the ischial tuberosity.

 

Option C. Adductor Magnus: It has an attachment to the ischial tuberosity, but it is primarily involved in adduction of the thigh and is less likely to be involved in sprinting injuries that present with pain at the ischial tuberosity.

 

Option D. Iliopsoas: This muscle primarily originates from the lumbar vertebrae and the iliac fossa and inserts on the lesser trochanter of the femur. It is not attached to the ischial tuberosity and thus is not likely involved in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Abdomen and Lower Limb, 3rd Edition, Vishram Singh, Volume II, Pg. 367

choices.text: Deep Inguinal Ring
Superficial Inguinal Ring
Femoral Artery
Inferior Epigastric Artery

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with a palpable mass in his groin during a routine physical examination. To determine the nature of the mass, it is essential to understand the anatomical landmarks in the groin area. Which structure is located at the mid inguinal point, a landmark situated midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic symphysis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Femoral Artery

 

Option C: The femoral artery passes directly underneath the mid inguinal point. This is a crucial landmark for procedures such as femoral artery catheterization.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the transversalis fascia. It is located superior to the midpoint of the inguinal ligament but not at the mid inguinal point.

 

Mid inguinal point - Mid point between Anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) and pubic symphysis


Mid point of inguinal ligament - mid point between ASIS and pubic tubercle.

 

Option B. Superficial Inguinal Ring is an opening in the external oblique aponeurosis. While it is near the mid inguinal point, it is not precisely located at this point.

 

Option D. Inferior Epigastric Artery arises from the external iliac artery and travels superiorly on the posterior surface of the rectus abdominis. It is not located at the mid inguinal point.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Femoral Artery: The femoral artery passes directly underneath the mid inguinal point. This is a crucial landmark for procedures such as femoral artery catheterization.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Abdomen and Lower Limb, 3rd Edition, Vishram Singh, Volume II, Pg. 338.

choices.text: Greater Sciatic Notch: Sciatic Nerve, Pudendal Nerve; Lesser Sciatic Notch: Superior Gluteal Artery
Greater Sciatic Notch: Sciatic Nerve, Superior Gluteal Artery; Lesser Sciatic Notch: Pudendal Nerve, Internal Pudendal Artery
Greater Sciatic Notch: Piriformis Muscle, Sciatic Nerve; Lesser Sciatic Notch: Tendon of Obturator Internus, Pudendal Nerve
Greater Sciatic Notch: Inferior Gluteal Artery, Nerve to Quadratus Femoris; Lesser Sciatic Notch: Sciatic Nerve, Nerve to Obturator Internus

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with sciatic nerve pain. Understanding the anatomy of the pelvis, specifically the structures passing through the greater and lesser sciatic notches, is crucial for diagnosing conditions affecting this nerve. Which of the following sets of structures correctly passes through the greater and lesser sciatic notches?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Greater Sciatic Notch: Piriformis Muscle, Sciatic Nerve; Lesser Sciatic Notch: Tendon of Obturator Internus, Pudendal Nerve

 

Option C: This is correct

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Greater sciatic notch: Sciatic nerve, Pudendal nerve; Lesser sciatic notch: Superior gluteal artery: This is incorrect as the pudendal nerve and internal pudendal vessels pass through the lesser sciatic notch after exiting the greater sciatic notch.

 

Option B. Greater sciatic notch: Sciatic nerve, Superior gluteal artery; Lesser sciatic notch: Pudendal nerve, Internal pudendal artery: The superior gluteal artery passes through the greater sciatic notch, but the pudendal nerve and internal pudendal artery pass through both notches.

 

Option D. Greater sciatic notch: Inferior gluteal artery, Nerve to quadratus femoris; Lesser sciatic notch: Sciatic nerve, Nerve to obturator internus: This is incorrect as the sciatic nerve passes through the greater sciatic notch, not the lesser.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The greater sciatic notch allows passage of the piriformis muscle and the sciatic nerve among other structures. The lesser sciatic notch allows passage of the tendon of the obturator internus and structures such as the pudendal nerve.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy, Abdomen and Lower Limb, 3rd Edition, Vishram Singh, Volume II, Pg. 356.

choices.text: Originates from the Anterior Tibial Artery and Enters the Tibia on its Anterior Surface
Originates from the Posterior Tibial Artery and Enters the Tibia on its Posterior Surface
Originates from the Fibular Artery and Enters the Tibia on its Lateral Surface
Originates from the Popliteal Artery and Enters the Tibia on its Posterior Surface

questions.text: During a clinical anatomy class, medical students are discussing the vascular supply of the lower limb bones. One student asks about the nutrient artery of the tibia. Which of the following statements best describes the characteristics and source of the nutrient artery of the tibia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Originates from the Posterior Tibial Artery and Enters the Tibia on its Posterior Surface

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Originates from the anterior tibial artery and enters the tibia on its anterior surface: The anterior tibial artery primarily supplies the anterior compartment of the leg, but it is not the source of the nutrient artery to the tibia.

 

Option C. Originates from the fibular artery and enters the tibia on its lateral surface: The fibular artery supplies the lateral compartment of the leg and the fibula, not the tibia.

 

Option D. Originates from the Popliteal Artery and Enters the Tibia on its Posterior Surface. Popliteal artery divides into anterior and posterior tibial artery. The posterior tibial artery gives off a nutrient artery to the tibia. Hence- the branch of the popliteal artery is not giving directly rise to the nutrient artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The nutrient artery of the tibia usually arises from the posterior tibial artery and enters the bone on its posterior surface. It is crucial for the blood supply to the shaft of the tibia.

 

Ref: Grays anatomy Pg 1400, 42nd edition

choices.text: Iliofemoral Ligament: Prevents Hyperextension of the Hip Joint
Ischiofemoral Ligament: Prevents Excessive Medial Rotation of the Hip Joint
Pubofemoral Ligament: Limits Abduction and External Rotation of the Hip Joint
Ligamentum Teres: Primary Stabilizer of the Hip Joint in all Movements

questions.text: A third-year medical student is studying the anatomy of the hip joint for an upcoming exam. Which of the following ligaments is correctly paired with its primary function in stabilizing the hip joint?
